nodes.text: Changing how students are allocated to colleges can substantially reduce income segregation across colleges and increase intergenerational mobility in the United States

We construct near-complete, college-level statistics linking deidentified federal tax records, Department of Education records (1098-T and NSLDS/Pell), and College Board/ACT to measure: parents' household income (averaged ages 15-19), child earnings (ages 32-34), college attendance (most attended ages 19-22), and SAT/ACT scores and race where observed

Parental income segregation across colleges is very high and comparable in magnitude to parental income segregation across precollege neighborhoods (ZIP codes); elite colleges are overwhelmingly populated by high-income families

Within the same college, differences in adult earnings between children from low- versus high-income parents are much smaller than national differences; controlling for college fixed effects reduces the national parent-child earnings rank gap from ~29 percentiles to ~11 percentiles

There exists substantial heterogeneity across colleges in upward mobility: some mid-tier public colleges (e.g., CUNY campuses, some California State and University of Texas campuses) combine large shares of low-income students with relatively high earnings outcomes, yielding high bottom-to-top-quintile mobility rates, while Ivy-Plus colleges have much higher rates of reaching the top 1%

High-achieving test-takers are concentrated among higher-income families: only a small fraction of students with SAT/ACT >= 1300 come from bottom-quintile families (about 3.7% of college-goers scoring 1300+), so elite colleges have few low-income applicants with very high test scores

We estimate the share of cross-college differences in conditional earnings (conditional on parent income, race, and test scores) that reflect colleges' causal effects versus selection by controlling for observables and application set; these exercises imply a large causal component, and we use an 80% causal share as a baseline in simulations

Counterfactual simulations: (a) income-neutral allocations (randomize within SAT/ACT-state-race cells) and (b) need-affirmative allocations (apply a sliding-scale SAT/ACT advantage to lower-income students, e.g., +160 SAT to bottom quintile, linearly smaller for middle quintiles), holding college seat counts, racial and geographic mixes fixed

Data construction choices: parental income = mean pretax household income when child age 15–19; child earnings = individual earnings in 2014 (ages 32–34); college assignment = most attended college age 19–22; SAT/ACT imputed for missing cases using state, race, college-tier, and earnings-based matching (validated in states with near-universal testing)

Evidence quantifying segregation: Ivy-Plus colleges have 14.5% of students from top 1% and only 3.8% from bottom quintile; children from top 1% are ~77x more likely to attend Ivy-Plus than bottom-quintile children; two-thirds of variation in bottom-quintile shares is within selectivity tiers

Evidence on within-college persistence: national parent-child rank slope ~0.288; including college fixed effects reduces slope to ~0.139; among college-goers with college FE slope ~0.10 and among elite colleges ~0.065, indicating much weaker parent-child persistence within colleges

Empirical mobility heterogeneity: mobility rate = fraction low-income × top-quintile outcome rate; some mid-tier public colleges have mobility rates >6–9% (top 10 list), while Ivy-Plus colleges have very high top-quintile outcome rates (mean ~58%) and especially high top-1% outcomes (~12.8%) but small low-income shares

Evidence on SAT-income joint distribution and undermatching: conditional on test-score level, higher-income students attend more selective colleges; there are relatively few high-scoring low-income students, limiting the effect of policies that rely only on recruiting high-scoring low-income applicants to elite private colleges

Estimates of causal share supporting simulations: regressions controlling for high-school fixed effects, SAT/ACT, race, and application-set variables yield implied retained college-value coefficients consistent with lambda roughly 0.8–0.9; baseline simulation uses 80% causal share and assumes colleges' causal effects unchanged under reallocations

Simulation result — income-neutral allocations: allocating students randomly within SAT/ACT-state-race cells would substantially reduce segregation (e.g., close ~64% of the gap in exposure of low-income students to top-quintile peers relative to perfect integration among college-goers) and would reduce the parent-child top-quintile outcome gap by about 15% assuming 80% causal share

Simulation result — need-affirmative allocations: granting a sliding preference equivalent to ~+160 SAT for bottom-quintile students (and smaller increments for higher quintiles) would essentially equalize parental income distributions across college tiers and reduce intergenerational persistence among college students by about 25% under the 80% causal-share baseline (larger effects for upper-tail mobility are possible)
